titleInfo.title: Characterizing the Interactions between Gene Delivery Polyplexes and Bio-Inspired Polymeric Surface Coatings for Localized Gene Therapy

name.namePart: Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering

mods:mods.abstract: Nucleic acid delivery is crucial for several biomedical applications, including tissue engineering, medical implant coatings, cancer treatment and regenerative medicine. Localized delivery of nucleic acids through biomaterial substrates can overcome several difficulties associated with common systemic delivery and maintain high vector concentrations at the target site to enable increased transfection efficiency. In this project, we aim to develop substrate-based nucleic acid delivery coatings that can provide extended and localized release of non-viral gene delivery vectors for tissue engineering and regenerative medicine applications. In vitro studies are conducted to characterize the absorption and release interactions between surface coatings made of the bio-inspired and naturally derived polymers, including polydopamine (pDA), hyaluronic acid (HA), glycol chitosan (GC), and their combinations, and a model polymeric gene delivery vector composed of polyethyleneimine (PEI). PEI-DNA polyplexes N/P ratio was observed to have a statistically significant impact on the amount of DNA loaded onto each coating, while the surface coating type and concentration were surprisingly found to have no statistically significant effects. Surface-based transfection as well as bolus transfection from these coatings are studied over time for NIH3T3 and HEK293 cells. Surface-based transfection efficiencies were significantly impacted by the coating types and polyplex N/P ratios for transfection on HEK293 cells. However, for transfection on NIH3T3 cells only coating type had a significant impact on the transfection efficiencies. In conclusion, this study adds to our understanding of how different biocompatible materials interact with nucleic acid delivery polyplexes, which aids in the creation of surface coatings that facilitate effective localized nucleic acid delivery for tissue engineering and biomedical implant applications.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
DNA-PEI polyplexes, localized release, polyethyleneimine, Surface-based transfection
Christina A. Holmes, Professor Directing Thesis; Tristan Driscoll, Committee Member; Jingjiao Guan, Committee Member.
